articles.title: Portugisiska Fraser fÃ¶r FÃ¶rlÃ¥telse
articles.content:
FÃ¶rlÃ¥telse, eller "perdÃ£o" pÃ¥ portugisiska, Ã¤r central i varma relationer. Dessa fraser hjÃ¤lper dig navigera fÃ¶rlÃ¥telse.

## Fraser fÃ¶r att Be om FÃ¶rlÃ¥telse

### 1. "Eu sinto muito"
**Uttal:** eh-oo seen-too moo-een-too

**Betydelse:** Jag Ã¤r verkligen ledsen

### 2. "Por favor, me perdoa"
**Uttal:** por fa-vor meh per-do-a

**Betydelse:** SnÃ¤lla fÃ¶rlÃ¥t mig

### 3. "Eu assumo toda a responsabilidade"
**Uttal:** eh-oo a-soo-moo to-da a res-pon-sa-bee-lee-da-deh

**Betydelse:** Jag tar fullt ansvar

### 4. "Eu estava errado/a e sei disso"
**Uttal:** eh-oo es-ta-va eh-ra-doo/a ee say dee-soo

**Betydelse:** Jag hade fel och jag vet det

### 5. "Como posso me redimir?"
**Uttal:** koh-moo po-soo meh reh-dee-meer

**Betydelse:** Hur kan jag gottgÃ¶ra det?

## Fraser fÃ¶r att Ge FÃ¶rlÃ¥telse

### 6. "Eu te perdoo"
**Uttal:** eh-oo teh per-do-oo

**Betydelse:** Jag fÃ¶rlÃ¥ter dig

### 7. "Vamos deixar isso para trÃ¡s"
**Uttal:** va-moos day-shar ee-soo pa-ra tras

**Betydelse:** LÃ¥t oss lÃ¤gga det bakom oss

### 8. "Eu entendo e agradeÃ§o suas desculpas"
**Uttal:** eh-oo en-ten-doo ee a-gra-deh-soo soo-as des-kool-pas

**Betydelse:** Jag fÃ¶rstÃ¥r och uppskattar din ursÃ¤kt

### 9. "Todos cometemos erros"
**Uttal:** to-doos koh-meh-teh-moos eh-roos

**Betydelse:** Vi gÃ¶r alla misstag

### 10. "Ã‰ preciso coragem para pedir desculpas"
**Uttal:** eh preh-see-zoo ko-ra-zhem pa-ra peh-deer des-kool-pas

**Betydelse:** Det krÃ¤vs mod att be om ursÃ¤kt

### 11. "AgradeÃ§o sua sinceridade"
**Uttal:** a-gra-deh-soo soo-a seen-seh-ree-da-deh

**Betydelse:** Jag uppskattar din uppriktighet

### 12. "O importante Ã© seguirmos em frente juntos"
**Uttal:** oo eem-por-tan-teh eh seh-geer-moos en fren-teh zhoon-toos

**Betydelse:** Det viktiga Ã¤r att vi gÃ¥r vidare tillsammans

## Avslutande Tankar

Med dessa fraser kan du be om och ge fÃ¶rlÃ¥telse med din portugisisktalande partner.

articles.title: Franske 'Jeg Savner Dig' SÃ¦tninger for Danskere
articles.content:
Fransk er kÃ¦rlighedens sprog, og det gÃ¦lder ogsÃ¥ nÃ¥r det handler om at udtrykke savn. De franske ord for at savne har en poetisk klang, der gÃ¸r selv de svÃ¦reste fÃ¸lelser smukke.

## At Savne pÃ¥ Fransk

Det franske "tu me manques" er interessant â€“ det oversÃ¦ttes bogstaveligt til "du mangler mig", som om den anden persons fravÃ¦r efterlader et fysisk tomrum. Det er en smuk mÃ¥de at tÃ¦nke pÃ¥ savn.

## GrundlÃ¦ggende Udtryk

### "Tu me manques"
**Udtale:** ty mÉ™ mÉ‘Ìƒk

**Betydning:** Jeg savner dig (bogstaveligt: Du mangler mig)

Den klassiske franske mÃ¥de at udtrykke savn. BemÃ¦rk den omvendte struktur.

### "Tu me manques tellement"
**Udtale:** ty mÉ™ mÉ‘Ìƒk tÉ›l-Mâ±­Ìƒ

**Betydning:** Jeg savner dig sÃ¥ meget

TilfÃ¸jer intensitet til udtrykket.

### "Je pense Ã  toi tout le temps"
**Udtale:** Ê’É™ pÉ‘Ìƒs a twa tu lÉ™ tÉ‘Ìƒ

**Betydning:** Jeg tÃ¦nker pÃ¥ dig hele tiden

Viser at personen konstant er i dine tanker.

## Dybere Udtryk

### "Chaque instant sans toi est une Ã©ternitÃ©"
**Udtale:** Êƒak É›Ìƒ-STÈºN sÉ‘Ìƒ twa É› tyn e-ter-ni-TE

**Betydning:** Hvert Ã¸jeblik uden dig er en evighed

Poetisk og typisk fransk i sin elegance.

### "Tu es la premiÃ¨re chose Ã  laquelle je pense en me rÃ©veillant"
**Udtale:** ty É› la prÉ™-MJER Êƒoz a la-KEL Ê’É™ pÉ‘Ìƒs É‘Ìƒ mÉ™ re-ve-Jâ±­Ìƒ

**Betydning:** Du er det fÃ¸rste, jeg tÃ¦nker pÃ¥, nÃ¥r jeg vÃ¥gner

Viser at din partner fylder dine morgentanker.

### "J'aimerais tellement que tu sois lÃ "
**Udtale:** Ê’É›m-RE tÉ›l-Mâ±­Ìƒ kÉ™ ty swa la

**Betydning:** Jeg ville sÃ¥ gerne have, at du var her

Udtrykker dyb lÃ¦ngsel efter nÃ¦rhed.

## Hverdagens Savn

### "Ton sourire me manque"
**Udtale:** tÉ”Ìƒ su-RIR mÉ™ mÉ‘Ìƒk

**Betydning:** Jeg savner dit smil

Specifikt og personligt.

### "M'endormir Ã  cÃ´tÃ© de toi me manque"
**Udtale:** mÉ‘Ìƒ-dor-MIR a ko-TE dÉ™ twa mÉ™ mÉ‘Ìƒk

**Betydning:** Jeg savner at falde i sÃ¸vn ved siden af dig

Intimt og kÃ¦rligt.

### "Nos conversations me manquent"
**Udtale:** no kÉ”Ìƒ-ver-sa-SJÆ†Ìƒ mÉ™ mÉ‘Ìƒk

**Betydning:** Jeg savner vores samtaler

Viser at du savner den dybe forbindelse.

## Romantiske Udtryk

### "Tu me manques plus que les mots ne peuvent le dire"
**Udtale:** ty mÉ™ mÉ‘Ìƒk ply kÉ™ le mo nÉ™ pÅ“v lÉ™ dir

**Betydning:** Jeg savner dig mere end ord kan udtrykke

NÃ¥r savnet overvÃ¦lder.

### "ÃŠtre loin de toi est la chose la plus difficile"
**Udtale:** É›tr lwÉ›Ìƒ dÉ™ twa É› la Êƒoz la ply di-fi-SIL

**Betydning:** At vÃ¦re langt fra dig er det svÃ¦reste

Udtrykker smerten ved adskillelse.

### "Je compte les jours jusqu'Ã  ce que je te revoie"
**Udtale:** Ê’É™ kÉ”Ìƒt le Ê’ur Ê’ys-ka sÉ™ kÉ™ Ê’É™ tÉ™ rÉ™-VWA

**Bedeutning:** Jeg tÃ¦ller dagene til jeg ser dig igen

Fokuseret pÃ¥ genforeningen.

## TrÃ¸stende SÃ¦tninger

### "La distance ne signifie rien quand quelqu'un signifie tout"
**Udtale:** la dis-Tâ±­ÌƒS nÉ™ si-nji-FI rjÉ›Ìƒ kÉ‘Ìƒ kel-KÆÌƒ si-nji-FI tu

**Betydning:** Afstand betyder intet, nÃ¥r nogen betyder alt

En smuk pÃ¥mindelse.

### "OÃ¹ que tu sois, tu es toujours dans mon cÅ“ur"
**Udtale:** u kÉ™ ty swa, ty É› tu-Ê’UR dÉ‘Ìƒ mÉ”Ìƒ kÅ“r

**Betydning:** Uanset hvor du er, er du altid i mit hjerte

TrÃ¸stende og poetisk.

## Franske Udtryk for LÃ¦ngsel

### "J'ai le mal de toi"
**Udtale:** Ê’e lÉ™ mal dÉ™ twa

**Betydning:** Jeg har savn-syge efter dig

Et smukt fransk idiom der beskriver savn som en form for "sygdom".

### "Mon cÅ“ur t'appelle"
**Udtale:** mÉ”Ìƒ kÅ“r ta-PEL

**Betydning:** Mit hjerte kalder pÃ¥ dig

Poetisk og romantisk.

## Kulturelle Tips

**Brevskrivning:** FranskmÃ¦nd sÃ¦tter pris pÃ¥ velskrevne breve. Overvej at sende et hÃ¥ndskrevet brev.

**SmÃ¥ beskeder:** "Bisou" (kys) eller "Je t'embrasse" (jeg krammer dig) er varme afslutninger pÃ¥ beskeder.

**Poesi:** At citere fransk poesi om kÃ¦rlighed og savn viser kulturel forstÃ¥else.

**Perfume:** At sende noget der dufter af dig er en romantisk fransk gestus.

## Afsluttende Ord

Fransk giver dig mulighed for at udtrykke savn med elegance og dybde. Den omvendte struktur "tu me manques" minder os om, at savn handler om det tomrum, den anden efterlader i vores liv.

Souviens-toi: L'absence est Ã  l'amour ce que le vent est au feu; il Ã©teint le petit, il allume le grand. (Husk: FravÃ¦r er for kÃ¦rlighed, hvad vind er for ild; den slukker den lille, den tÃ¦nder den store.)

articles.title: Ukrainische Aussprache fÃ¼r Deutsche
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Das ukrainische Alphabet mag auf den ersten Blick einschÃ¼chternd wirken, aber als deutscher Muttersprachler hast du einige Vorteile. Viele Laute sind Ã¤hnlich, und mit etwas Ãœbung wirst du das kyrillische Alphabet schnell beherrschen.

## Das Kyrillische Alphabet

Das ukrainische Alphabet hat 33 Buchstaben. Hier sind sie mit ihrer Aussprache:

### Buchstaben wie im Deutschen

| Kyrillisch | Laut | Wie in... | Beispiel |
|------------|------|-----------|----------|
| **Ğ Ğ°** | a | Vater | Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ° (MA-ma) |
| **Ğ Ğ¾** | o | Mond | Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğµ (DOB-re) |
| **Ğ• Ğµ** | e | Bett | Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ (denj) |
| **Ğ† Ñ–** | i | Tier | Ğ»Ñ–Ğ¶ĞºĞ¾ (LISCH-ko) |
| **Ğ£ Ñƒ** | u | Mut | Ğ´ÑƒĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ (DU-ma-ty) |
| **Ğœ Ğ¼** | m | Mutter | Ğ¼Ñ–ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ (MIS-to) |
| **Ğ Ğ½** | n | Nase | Ğ½Ñ– (ni) |
| **Ğš Ğº** | k | Kalt | ĞºĞ°Ğ²Ğ° (KA-wa) |
| **Ğ¢ Ñ‚** | t | Tag | Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº (tak) |
| **Ğ¡ Ñ** | s | Glas | ÑĞ¾Ğ½ (son) |

### Buchstaben mit anderen Lauten

| Kyrillisch | Laut | ErklÃ¤rung | Beispiel |
|------------|------|-----------|----------|
| **Ğ’ Ğ²** | w | wie deutsches W | Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ° (wo-DA) |
| **Ğ“ Ğ³** | h | stimmhaftes H | Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ° (ho-lo-WA) |
| **Ğ” Ğ´** | d | wie deutsches D | Ğ´Ñ–Ğ¼ (dim) |
| **Ğ– Ğ¶** | sch (stimmhaft) | wie J in Journal | Ğ¶Ñ–Ğ½ĞºĞ° (SCHIN-ka) |
| **Ğ— Ğ·** | s (stimmhaft) | wie in Rose | Ğ·ĞµĞ¼Ğ»Ñ (sem-LYA) |
| **Ğ™ Ğ¹** | j | wie deutsches J | Ğ¹Ñ‚Ğ¸ (j-ty) |
| **Ğ› Ğ»** | l | wie deutsches L | Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ¾Ğ² (lyu-BOW) |
| **ĞŸ Ğ¿** | p | wie deutsches P | Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ñ–Ñ‚ (pry-WIT) |
| **Ğ  Ñ€** | r | gerolltes R | Ñ€ÑƒĞºĞ° (ru-KA) |
| **Ğ¤ Ñ„** | f | wie deutsches F | Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾ (FO-to) |

<CultureTip title="Das ukrainische Ğ“" flag="ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦">
Das ukrainische Ğ“ (Ğ³) wird als stimmhaftes H ausgesprochen, Ã¤hnlich dem englischen "h" in "hello", aber mit mehr Stimme. Es ist NICHT wie das deutsche "g"!
</CultureTip>

### Besondere ukrainische Buchstaben

| Kyrillisch | Laut | ErklÃ¤rung | Beispiel |
|------------|------|-----------|----------|
| **Ğ‘ Ğ±** | b | wie deutsches B | Ğ±Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒĞºĞ¾ (BAT-ko) |
| **Ğ¦ Ñ†** | ts | wie in "Zar" | Ñ†Ñ–ĞºĞ°Ğ²Ğ¾ (tsi-KA-wo) |
| **Ğ§ Ñ‡** | tsch | wie in "TschÃ¼ss" | Ñ‡Ğ°Ñ (tschas) |
| **Ğ¨ Ñˆ** | sch | wie in "Schule" | ÑˆĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ° (SCHKO-la) |
| **Ğ© Ñ‰** | schtsch | langes sch+tsch | Ñ‰Ğµ (schtsche) |
| **Ğ¬ ÑŒ** | - | macht Konsonant weich | Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ (denj) |
| **Ğ˜ Ğ¸** | y | zwischen i und Ã¼ | ÑĞ¸Ğ½ (syn) |
| **Ğ‡ Ñ—** | ji | wie deutsches "ji" | Ñ—Ğ¶Ğ° (JI-scha) |
| **Ğ„ Ñ”** | je | wie deutsches "je" | Ğ„Ğ²Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ° (jew-RO-pa) |
| **Ğ® Ñ** | ju | wie deutsches "ju" | ÑĞ½Ğ°Ğº (ju-NAK) |
| **Ğ¯ Ñ** | ja | wie deutsches "ja" | Ñ (ja) |

<VocabCard
  word="ĞŸÑ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ñ–Ñ‚"
  translation="Hallo"
  pronunciation="pry-WIT"
  example="ĞŸÑ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ñ–Ñ‚, ÑĞº ÑĞ¿Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸?"
/>

## Ausspracheregeln

### 1. Betonung

Die Betonung im Ukrainischen ist nicht festgelegt und kann auf jeder Silbe liegen. Die falsche Betonung kann die Bedeutung Ã¤ndern!

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğº"
  translation="Schloss (GebÃ¤ude) / Schloss (TÃ¼r)"
  pronunciation="SA-mok / sa-MOK"
  example="Die Betonung Ã¤ndert die Bedeutung!"
/>

### 2. Stimmlose und stimmhafte Konsonanten

Am Wortende werden stimmhafte Konsonanten NICHT stimmlos wie im Deutschen:

| Ukrainisch | Aussprache | NICHT |
|------------|------------|-------|
| **Ñ…Ğ»Ñ–Ğ±** (Brot) | chlib | chlip |
| **ÑĞ°Ğ´** (Garten) | sad | sat |

### 3. Das weiche Zeichen (Ğ¬)

Das weiche Zeichen macht den vorhergehenden Konsonanten weich (palatalisiert):

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ"
  translation="Tag"
  pronunciation="denj"
  example="Ğ”Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ! (Guten Tag!)"
/>

### 4. Der Apostroph

Der Apostroph trennt harte Konsonanten von Jotierungsvokalen:

| Wort | Aussprache | Bedeutung |
|------|------------|-----------|
| **Ğ¼'ÑÑĞ¾** | M-JA-so | Fleisch |
| **Ğ¿'ÑÑ‚ÑŒ** | P-JATJ | fÃ¼nf |

## ÃœbungssÃ¤tze

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Ğ”Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½ĞºÑƒ"
  translation="Guten Morgen"
  pronunciation="DOB-ro-ho RAN-ku"
  context="Eine freundliche BegrÃ¼ÃŸung am Morgen."
/>

### Grundlegende BegrÃ¼ÃŸungen

| Ukrainisch | Aussprache | Deutsch |
|------------|------------|---------|
| ĞŸÑ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ñ–Ñ‚ | pry-WIT | Hallo |
| Ğ”Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ | DOB-ryj denj | Guten Tag |
| Ğ”Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²ĞµÑ‡Ñ–Ñ€ | DOB-ryj WE-tschir | Guten Abend |
| ĞĞ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ñ–Ñ‡ | na dob-RA-nitsch | Gute Nacht |
| Ğ”ÑĞºÑƒÑ | DYA-ku-ju | Danke |
| Ğ‘ÑƒĞ´ÑŒ Ğ»Ğ°ÑĞºĞ° | budj LAS-ka | Bitte |

<CultureTip title="Aussprache-Tipp" flag="ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦">
Ãœbe jeden Tag 10 Minuten das laute Lesen. Die ukrainische Aussprache wird natÃ¼rlicher, je mehr du sprichst. Scheue dich nicht vor Fehlern - dein Partner wird deine BemÃ¼hungen schÃ¤tzen!
</CultureTip>

## HÃ¤ufige Fehler von Deutschen

1. **Das Ğ“ wie deutsches G aussprechen** - Es ist ein stimmhaftes H!
2. **Konsonanten am Wortende stimmlos machen** - Halte sie stimmhaft
3. **Das Ğ˜ wie deutsches I aussprechen** - Es ist ein Laut zwischen i und Ã¼
4. **Die Betonung ignorieren** - Sie kann die Bedeutung Ã¤ndern

## NÃ¤chste Schritte

Beginne mit dem Lesen einfacher WÃ¶rter und steigere dich zu lÃ¤ngeren SÃ¤tzen. Mit regelmÃ¤ÃŸiger Ãœbung wirst du das kyrillische Alphabet bald flieÃŸend lesen kÃ¶nnen!

<CTA />

articles.title: Turkish Pronunciation: Master Key Sounds
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Turkish pronunciation is one of the most rewarding aspects of the language because it's completely phonetic. Once you learn how each letter sounds, you can read and pronounce any Turkish word correctly. No guessing, no exceptions. Let's master every sound.

## The Golden Rule of Turkish

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Turkce fonetiktir"
  translation="Turkish is phonetic"
  pronunciation="TEWRK-cheh foh-neh-TEEK-teer"
  context="What you see is what you say. Every letter has exactly one sound, and every sound is always spelled the same way."
/>

Unlike English where "cough," "through," and "though" all have different "ough" sounds, Turkish is beautifully consistent. Once you learn the 29 letters, you can pronounce anything.

## The Turkish Alphabet

Turkish uses 29 letters: 8 vowels and 21 consonants. It's based on the Latin alphabet but has some unique characters.

### The 8 Vowels

Turkish vowels are divided into "front" and "back" vowels. This matters for vowel harmony (suffixes match the vowel type of the root word).

<ConjugationTable
  verb="Front Vowels"
  meaning="Pronounced toward the front of the mouth"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "E e", word: "ev (house)", translation: "Like 'e' in 'bed'" },
    { person: "I i", word: "il (province)", translation: "Like 'ee' in 'see'" },
    { person: "O o", word: "ot (grass)", translation: "Like 'o' in 'more'" },
    { person: "U u", word: "un (flour)", translation: "Like 'oo' in 'boot'" }
  ]}
/>

<ConjugationTable
  verb="Back Vowels"
  meaning="Pronounced toward the back of the mouth"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "A a", word: "at (horse)", translation: "Like 'a' in 'father'" },
    { person: "I Ä±", word: "Ä±lÄ±k (warm)", translation: "Like 'u' in 'cushion' (no English equivalent)" },
    { person: "O o", word: "ot (grass)", translation: "Like 'o' in 'more'" },
    { person: "U u", word: "un (flour)", translation: "Like 'oo' in 'boot'" }
  ]}
/>

### The Special Vowels

Two vowels need special attention because they don't exist in English:

<VocabCard
  word="I Ä± (dotless i)"
  translation="The 'uh' sound"
  pronunciation="Like 'u' in 'cushion' or the second 'a' in 'sofa'"
  example="IsÄ±k (light), sÄ±cak (hot), kÄ±rmÄ±zÄ± (red)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="O o (soft o)"
  translation="The 'ur' sound"
  pronunciation="Like 'ur' in 'fur' but with rounded lips"
  example="Goz (eye), koprÃ¼ (bridge), gÃ¶rmek (to see)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="U u (soft u)"
  translation="The 'ew' sound"
  pronunciation="Like 'u' in French 'tu' - say 'ee' with rounded lips"
  example="Gun (day), gÃ¼zel (beautiful), gÃ¼lmek (to laugh)"
/>

<CultureTip title="The Dotless I Trap" flag="ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡·">
The dotless I (I Ä±) is the most challenging letter for English speakers. It's NOT the same as the English "i" - it's a completely different sound. Practice by saying "cushion" and focusing on that quick "uh" sound. "Istanbul" in Turkish is actually "Ä°stanbul" with a dotted I!
</CultureTip>

## Consonants That Differ From English

Most Turkish consonants sound like English, but several are different:

### C c - The "J" Sound

<VocabCard
  word="C c"
  translation="Like 'j' in 'jam'"
  pronunciation="'j' as in 'jungle'"
  example="Can (soul) = 'jahn', cok (very) = 'johk'"
/>

This trips up English speakers who expect 'c' to sound like 'k' or 's'. In Turkish, C always sounds like English J.

### C c - The "CH" Sound

<VocabCard
  word="C c (c-cedilla)"
  translation="Like 'ch' in 'church'"
  pronunciation="'ch' as in 'cheese'"
  example="Cok (very) = 'chohk', cocuk (child) = 'cho-JOOK'"
/>

### S s - The "SH" Sound

<VocabCard
  word="S s (s-cedilla)"
  translation="Like 'sh' in 'shoe'"
  pronunciation="'sh' as in 'sheep'"
  example="Sekerima (sugar) = 'sheh-keh-REEM', ÅŸimdi (now) = 'sheem-DEE'"
/>

### G g - The Silent Extender

<VocabCard
  word="G g (soft g)"
  translation="Silent - lengthens the previous vowel"
  pronunciation="Extends the vowel before it"
  example="DaÄŸ (mountain) = 'daa', soÄŸuk (cold) = 'so-ook'"
/>

This letter doesn't make a sound! It just makes the vowel before it longer. Think of it as a "vowel stretcher."

### H h - Always Pronounced

<VocabCard
  word="H h"
  translation="Like 'h' in 'hello' - always pronounced"
  pronunciation="Never silent like in 'hour'"
  example="Hayat (life) = 'hah-YAHT', Allah = 'ahl-LAHH'"
/>

<CultureTip title="The R Sound" flag="ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡·">
Turkish R is slightly rolled or tapped, similar to Spanish. It's never the American "r" sound. Practice by tapping your tongue against the roof of your mouth just behind your teeth. Listen to your partner say words with R and imitate them.
</CultureTip>

## Complete Consonant Guide

<ConjugationTable
  verb="Turkish Consonants"
  meaning="Complete pronunciation guide"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "B b", word: "Like English 'b'", translation: "bir (one), baba (father)" },
    { person: "C c", word: "Like 'j' in jam", translation: "can (soul), cep (pocket)" },
    { person: "C c", word: "Like 'ch' in church", translation: "cay (tea), cocuk (child)" },
    { person: "D d", word: "Like English 'd'", translation: "da (also), dil (tongue)" },
    { person: "F f", word: "Like English 'f'", translation: "fil (elephant), fare (mouse)" },
    { person: "G g", word: "Like 'g' in go", translation: "gel (come), goz (eye)" },
    { person: "G g", word: "Silent (extends vowel)", translation: "daÄŸ (mountain), soÄŸuk (cold)" },
    { person: "H h", word: "Like 'h' (always said)", translation: "hayat (life), her (every)" },
    { person: "J j", word: "Like 's' in measure", translation: "jilet (razor), garaj (garage)" },
    { person: "K k", word: "Like English 'k'", translation: "kedi (cat), kitap (book)" },
    { person: "L l", word: "Like English 'l'", translation: "lira, limon (lemon)" },
    { person: "M m", word: "Like English 'm'", translation: "masa (table), mavi (blue)" },
    { person: "N n", word: "Like English 'n'", translation: "ne (what), neden (why)" },
    { person: "P p", word: "Like English 'p'", translation: "para (money), pasta (cake)" },
    { person: "R r", word: "Tapped/rolled 'r'", translation: "renk (color), araba (car)" },
    { person: "S s", word: "Like English 's'", translation: "su (water), saat (hour)" },
    { person: "S s", word: "Like 'sh' in shop", translation: "ÅŸeker (sugar), ÅŸimdi (now)" },
    { person: "T t", word: "Like English 't'", translation: "tuz (salt), telefon" },
    { person: "V v", word: "Like English 'v'", translation: "var (exists), ve (and)" },
    { person: "Y y", word: "Like English 'y'", translation: "yol (road), yeni (new)" },
    { person: "Z z", word: "Like English 'z'", translation: "zor (difficult), zaman (time)" }
  ]}
/>

## Stress Patterns

Turkish stress is generally predictable:

### Basic Rule
Most words are stressed on the **last syllable**:

<VocabCard
  word="KitAP"
  translation="Book"
  pronunciation="kee-TAHP (stress on TAP)"
  example="Bu kitap cok guzel."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="AnkARA"
  translation="Ankara (capital city)"
  pronunciation="ahn-kah-RAH (stress on RA)"
  example="Ankara'da yasiyorum."
/>

### Exceptions
Place names and borrowed words often stress earlier syllables:

<VocabCard
  word="IStanbul"
  translation="Istanbul"
  pronunciation="ees-tahn-BOOL (stress on BOOL)"
  example="Istanbul'a gidiyorum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="loKANta"
  translation="Restaurant"
  pronunciation="loh-KAHN-tah"
  example="Bu lokantada yemek yiyelim."
/>

## Common Pronunciation Mistakes

### Mistake 1: Pronouncing C as K or S

<VocabCard
  word="Incorrect: 'seh-VEE-yorum'"
  translation="Common mistake with 'seviyorum'"
  pronunciation="Remember: C is like J!"
  example="Correct: 'seh-vee-YO-room' - the C in 'cok' is 'chok'"
/>

### Mistake 2: Ignoring the Dotless I

<VocabCard
  word="Incorrect: Istanbul"
  translation="Should be Ä°stanbul with dotted Ä°"
  pronunciation="The first I is dotted: ees-tahn-BOOL"
  example="Turkiye (Turkey) uses the dotless Ä±: TEWR-kee-yeh"
/>

### Mistake 3: Pronouncing G Like G

<VocabCard
  word="Incorrect: dag (mountain)"
  translation="Should NOT sound like English 'dag'"
  pronunciation="G is silent! Say: 'daa' with a long 'a'"
  example="Soguk (cold) = 'so-ook' not 'so-gook'"
/>

### Mistake 4: Swallowing the H

<VocabCard
  word="Incorrect: 'ayat' for 'hayat'"
  translation="The H must always be pronounced"
  pronunciation="Turkish H is never silent like English 'hour'"
  example="Hayatim (my life) = 'hah-YAH-tuhm' with clear H"
/>

<CultureTip title="Practice With Your Partner" flag="ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡·">
The best way to perfect your pronunciation is to practice with your Turkish partner. Ask them to correct you gently. Turkish speakers will be delighted that you're learning and will happily help you get the sounds right. Don't be shy about asking "how do you say this?"
</CultureTip>

## Practice Words by Sound

### Practice the Dotless I (Ä±)

<VocabCard
  word="IÅŸÄ±k"
  translation="Light"
  pronunciation="uh-SHUHK"
  example="IsÄ±ÄŸÄ± acar mÄ±sÄ±n? (Can you turn on the light?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="KÄ±rmÄ±zÄ±"
  translation="Red"
  pronunciation="kuhr-muh-ZUH"
  example="KÄ±rmÄ±zÄ± elbise cok guzel."
/>

### Practice the Soft O (o)

<VocabCard
  word="Goz"
  translation="Eye"
  pronunciation="gurz (with rounded lips)"
  example="Gozlerin cok guzel."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="KoprÃ¼"
  translation="Bridge"
  pronunciation="kur-PREW"
  example="BoÄŸaz Koprusu (Bosphorus Bridge)"
/>

### Practice the Soft U (u)

<VocabCard
  word="Gun"
  translation="Day"
  pronunciation="gewn"
  example="Bugun cok guzel bir gun."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Guzel"
  translation="Beautiful"
  pronunciation="gew-ZEL"
  example="Cok guzelsin. (You are very beautiful.)"
/>

### Practice the Soft G (g)

<VocabCard
  word="DaÄŸ"
  translation="Mountain"
  pronunciation="daa (long 'a')"
  example="Bu daÄŸ cok yuksek."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="YaÄŸmur"
  translation="Rain"
  pronunciation="yaa-MOOR"
  example="Yagmur yagiyor. (It's raining.)"
/>

## Romantic Phrases to Practice

Put it all together with these phrases for your partner:

<VocabCard
  word="Seni cok seviyorum"
  translation="I love you very much"
  pronunciation="SEH-nee chok seh-vee-YO-room"
  example="Canim, seni cok seviyorum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Gozlerin cok guzel"
  translation="Your eyes are very beautiful"
  pronunciation="gurz-leh-REEN chok gew-ZEL"
  example="Biliyorsun, gozlerin cok guzel."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Seninle cok mutluyum"
  translation="I'm very happy with you"
  pronunciation="seh-NEEN-leh chok moot-loo-YOOM"
  example="Hayatim, seninle cok mutluyum."
/>

## Quick Reference Chart

| Letter | Sound | Example Word | Pronunciation |
|--------|-------|--------------|---------------|
| C c | J as in jam | can (soul) | jahn |
| C c | CH as in church | cay (tea) | chai |
| G g | Silent (extends vowel) | dag (mountain) | daa |
| H h | H (always said) | hayat (life) | hah-YAHT |
| I Ä± | U as in cushion | Ä±lÄ±k (warm) | uh-LUHK |
| O o | UR with rounded lips | goz (eye) | gurz |
| S s | SH as in shop | ÅŸeker (sugar) | sheh-KER |
| U u | French U (ee + round lips) | gun (day) | gewn |

## Tips for Success

1. **Listen repeatedly**: Before speaking, listen to Turkish music, TV shows, and your partner
2. **Practice the unique sounds**: Spend extra time on Ä±, o, u, and ÄŸ
3. **Record yourself**: Compare your pronunciation to native speakers
4. **Go slowly**: Speed will come naturally; accuracy matters first
5. **Don't be afraid**: Turkish speakers love hearing foreigners try their language

> **Remember**: Perfect pronunciation takes time. Your partner fell in love with you, not your accent. They'll find your efforts charming and will help you improve. Every attempt shows you care.

<CTA
  text="Ready to master Turkish together?"
  buttonText="Start Learning Now"
/>
